image.altText: Chris Woakes holds his arms in the air and yells in delight

items.synopsis: England wins the third Test by three wickets, chasing down 251 runs for victory to keep the Ashes series alive. Follow live.

title.children: England keeps Ashes alive, winning third Test with thrilling run chase at Headingley

image.altText: A beautiful steaming hot spring in a Japanese village

items.synopsis: There's nothing quite like soaking in one of Japan's natural hot springs. But resort owners are refusing to share the geothermal energy reserves that could transform this resource-poor nation.

title.children: Japan sits on top of a huge reserve of clean, cheap power. Some call it 'devil energy'

image.altText: A smiling man sitting with a group of people in grey jumpsuits and white helmets in the background

items.synopsis: Xavier Doerr gives thanks to those involved in his rescue mission in 'extremely treacherous conditions' in the Great Australian Bight, after suffering injuries during an attempt to break several records circumnavigating Australia.

title.children: 'Very grateful': Sailor thanks rescuers after 'terrifying' ordeal during record attempt

image.altText: Centrelink sign.

items.synopsis: The Robodebt scandal didn't occur in a cultural vacuum. It was the end-point of decades of certain unemployment policies, writes Gareth Hutchens.

title.children: Robodebt was a scandal. Should economists bear some responsibility for it too?

image.altText: A sign that says 'Mitchell Freeway'.

items.synopsis: Motorists will be able to travel on the newest section of Perth's Mitchell Freeway from Monday, after the completion of a 5.6 kilometre extension to the northern suburb of Alkimos.

title.children: Newest section of Perth's Mitchell Freeway set to open to drivers

image.altText: young person with smoke coming out of their mouth after vaping

items.synopsis: Drug experts warn of the 'Uberisation' of e-cigarettes, saying young people now prefer to purchase vapes from social media apps like Snapchat, making it hard for police to track illegal activity.

title.children: Teens hospitalised with vaping-related vomiting and seizures, as experts warn of 'Uberisation' of drug selling

image.altText: A man in goggle chest deep in ocean

items.synopsis: An ocean swimmer who was in sight of land when disaster struck is ready to take on the Irish Sea once more to complete a global challenge.

title.children: Swimmer ready to try again after jellyfish cruel gruelling channel attempt

image.altText: a man walks through water at a lake with a bucket

items.synopsis: Worried residents gathered at Lake Eppalock in central Victoria are calling for the state government to release more water, fearing more flooding if there is significant rain.

title.children: Lake Eppalock set to spill as anxious residents call for more help

image.altText: A large aerial drone with a dome at the front and a propeller at the back is on display during an air show.

items.synopsis: The US Central Command says it conducted a drone strike that killed the ISIS leader Usamah al-Muhajir in eastern Syria.

title.children: US drone strike kills an ISIS leader in eastern Syria

image.altText: Zelenskyy and another man holding lanterns and looking sorrowful with priests in the background

items.synopsis: The Ukrainian president and his Polish counterpart remember the anniversary of the Volhynia massacre in which tens of thousands of Poles were killed.

title.children: Zelenskyy pays tribute to victims of WWII massacre of Poles by Ukrainian nationalists

image.altText: Soldiers push wooden boxes of cargo.

items.synopsis: Human rights groups and world leaders have spoken out against a decision from the United States to provide Ukraine with cluster munitions.

title.children: Canada, Spain among countries criticising US supply of cluster bombs to Ukraine

image.altText: Copy of Cricket1

items.synopsis: Carlton's late run to September continuies with victory in the west, after Essendon and Geelong claimed crucial points earlier in the day. Check out all the scores, stats and match reports here.

title.children: AFL Sunday wrap: Blues back in finals mix after Bombers and Cats claim crucial wins

image.altText: A shirtless man screams in celebration in the fighting octagon.

items.synopsis: Australian UFC star Alexander Volkanovksi puts in a brutal performance against Yair Rodriguez to claim the featherweight title at UFC 290.

title.children: Brutal Volkanovski claims back featherweight title, as fellow Aussie Whittaker falls to South African

image.altText: Photo of sandstone building with canon at front. Tree in left corner with concrete in it.

items.synopsis: Rotting and riddled with wasps, in the 1980s an ailing blue gum at Anglesea Barracks was filled with concrete to stabilise it. Almost four decades on the old tree still stands, is still alive, and the concrete is barely visible.

title.children: Rotting away from the inside out, this blue gum was filled with concrete. Four decades later it's stronger than ever

image.altText: A woman works inside a cannabis shop.

items.synopsis: As discussion ramps up to relax cannabis laws across Australia, experts say it's important to look at what's happened in Thailand one year since marijuana was decriminalised.

title.children: 'Sorry, we're stoned': What can Australia learn from Thailand a year after weed became legal?

image.altText: A young woman singing on a stage.

items.synopsis: There may be a frenzy over tickets for Taylor Swift, but for smaller fish in the music scene like Perth band Joan & The Giants, the post-pandemic landscape is tough — possibly tougher than it has ever been.

title.children: Musicians investing house deposits, taking on second jobs to survive as touring costs soar

image.altText: A police car and tape

items.synopsis: An 18-year-old man and two 17-year-old boys have been arrested and charged by police over the June stabbing attack.

title.children: Trio charged with murder over stabbing death of 14-year-old in Melbourne's north-west

image.altText: A band of four people poses against a beige backdrop.

items.synopsis: Ten Australian albums might feature in the top-50 ARIA chart each week a decade ago, but now there's more likely just one or two. Industry insiders say it's a crisis for local artists.

title.children: This Australian band topped the ARIA charts, but it's part of a dying breed

image.altText: A woman holding a baby looks out a hole in the wall

items.synopsis: Israeli forces have concluded their largest-scale military operation in the occupied West Bank city of Jenin in decades. But many say this raid could be the beginning of a major escalation.

title.children: Israel launched a huge raid on a Palestinian refugee camp. Here's why it could change everything

image.altText: A man sells artwork at a stall

items.synopsis: Hobart is known for its cafe culture — and there's a new kid on the block, looking to offer something slightly different.

title.children: New cafe helping migrants and mixing business with pleasure

image.altText: Muddy police officers using teamwork to exit Brisbane River

items.synopsis: Police divers are often dealing with unfavourable conditions, and in Queensland that can mean swimming in croc-infested waters. Here's how the specialist Dive Unit cops are selected.

title.children: Ever wondered what it takes to be a police diver? The four-day selection process is 'smelly and uncomfortable'

image.altText: Protesters stage a rally against the Japanese government's decision to release treated radioactive water.

items.synopsis: Worries about the safety of Japan's planned release of Fukushima's wastewater is sparking protests and boycotts in China and South Korea, but experts say the anxiety is not based in scientific facts.

title.children: Anxiety grows across Asia Pacific nations ahead of planned Fukushima wastewater release

image.altText: a man walks through water at a lake with a bucket

items.synopsis: Worried residents gathered at Lake Eppalock in central Victoria are calling for the state government to release more water, fearing more flooding if there is significant rain.

title.children: Lake Eppalock set to spill as anxious residents call for more help

image.altText: A young boy in a red baseball cap and a woman sit at a table filling in forms.

items.synopsis: Indigenous residents in the Kimberley region of WA, including some who never received a birth certificate, are being empowered with recognised identification.

title.children: Outback residents to 'take some control' with new community-led IDs

image.altText: A young man in blue shirt, black jeans, brown boots,glasses, rides on a bicycle past a white building.

items.synopsis: By the end of the year, the Bureau of Meteorology will have automated every weather station in regional mainland Australia. Except this one, in the heart of the outback.

title.children: Just how isolated this weather station is takes some explaining. But that's not what makes it unique

image.altText: time lapse image of satellites orbiting over a astronomy station

items.synopsis: Scientists, looking deep into space, have long voiced their concerns that satellites are encroaching on their ability to study the cosmos.

title.children: Scientists prove Elon Musk's Starlink satellites are interfering with ability to study the cosmos

image.altText: Jane Bari in the garden

items.synopsis: A hearty garden and empty freezer have helped Jane Bari and her husband go from having just $100 to their names to a life free of debt, and something that could help other older Australians out of poverty.

title.children: How one couple changed their lifestyle to live below their means

image.altText: A woman looking at an old glucose machine for diabetes

items.synopsis: In the 1970s, Stanley Clark wanted to stop his little girl's suffering. So, he built the world's first portable blood glucose monitoring machine in a New South Wales suburban backyard.

title.children: Stanley Clark's sweetest invention was made for his daughter. It's since helped millions of diabetes sufferers

image.altText: Model of spine against scientific diagrams of the spine

items.synopsis: Over centuries, posture has been linked to chronic back pain. Research has debunked this for decades, so why do we still believe it?

title.children: How pseudoscience and racism influenced the idea of 'good posture'

image.altText: Two men stand in front of a mound of dirt.

items.synopsis: Collins says many First Nations people would be able to relate to the characters in Limbo, a film about the disappearance of a young woman from an outback town.

title.children: 'Like a muffled scream': Rob Collins on making outback noir film Limbo
